security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill teaching uv package manager usage. Static findings detected shell pipe patterns and PowerShell commands which are the official installation methods from astral.sh. All detected patterns are standard documentation for legitimate software installation and represent false positives.

content.user_title: Master uv for fast Python dependency management
content.value_statement: Python projects need faster dependency setup than pip provides. This skill provides uv commands for project initialization, dependency management, virtual environments, and lockfile workflows.
actual_capabilities: Initialize new Python projects with uv init and standard project files
Add, remove, and upgrade dependencies using uv add and uv remove commands
Create and activate virtual environments with uv venv and uv run
Generate and update lockfiles with uv lock and uv sync for reproducible builds
Install and manage Python versions with uv python install and uv python pin
Configure pyproject.toml with dependency groups and workspace settings
limitations: Does not install uv automatically; users must run the official installer first
Contains documentation only; does not execute commands or modify the system
Assumes access to a command line environment with uv installed
Does not manage non-Python system dependencies or build tools

use_cases.title: Speed up local setup
use_cases.description: Start a new project quickly with uv init, add dependencies, and run tests without manual venv activation.

use_cases.title: Reproducible CI installs
use_cases.description: Use uv lock and uv sync --frozen to keep CI builds consistent and fast across all environments.

use_cases.title: Standardize team tooling
use_cases.description: Adopt uv workflows for team projects and migrate existing projects from pip or poetry.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Show the exact uv commands to create a project, add requests and pytest, and run tests without activating the venv.

prompt_templates.title: Dependency update
prompt_templates.prompt: List uv commands to update all dependencies, refresh the lockfile, and check for outdated packages.

prompt_templates.title: Python version pin
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to install Python 3.12 with uv and pin it for the project so all team members use the same version.

prompt_templates.title: CI pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a uv-based CI workflow that installs Python, syncs dependencies with frozen lockfiles, and runs tests.

output_examples.input: Give me the uv steps to create a project, add fastapi, and run tests.
output: Run `uv init my-app` to create a new project with virtual environment
Enter the project directory and add dependencies with `uv add fastapi`
Add test dependencies with `uv add --dev pytest`
Run tests using `uv run pytest` without activating the venv

output_examples.input: How do I migrate my existing project from pip to uv?
output: Install uv using the official installer for your platform
Run `uv add -r requirements.txt` to convert existing requirements
Generate a lockfile with `uv lock` for reproducible installs
Use `uv sync` to install all dependencies in the future
Commit uv.lock to version control for team consistency

output_examples.input: Set up a Docker container with uv for Python dependencies.
output: Use the official uv Docker image or install uv in your Dockerfile
Copy pyproject.toml and uv.lock before application code
Run `uv sync --frozen --no-dev` to install production dependencies
Use `uv run python app.py` to run your application with the correct environment

best_practices: Always commit uv.lock and pin Python versions with .python-version for reproducible builds
Use `uv run` instead of manually activating virtual environments to ensure correct tool usage
Use `uv sync --frozen` in CI pipelines to guarantee consistent dependency resolution
anti_patterns: Using curl or PowerShell pipe installs from untrusted or unofficial sources
Skipping lockfiles in CI and relying on floating dependency versions
Mixing pip and uv install commands without a clear workflow, which causes conflicts

faq.question: Is uv compatible with existing pyproject.toml files?
faq.answer: Yes, uv reads standard pyproject.toml and can work with existing Poetry and pip-tools projects.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides documentation and guidance only. Users must install uv first and execute commands themselves.

faq.question: Can I integrate uv with CI and Docker?
faq.answer: Yes, uv includes workflows for GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, and Docker multi-stage builds with lockfiles.

faq.question: Does this skill access my files or transmit data?
faq.answer: No, it is a static guide that provides documentation. It does not read files or make network requests.

faq.question: What should I try if uv command is not found?
faq.answer: Check your PATH settings or reinstall uv using the official installer from astral.sh as shown in the documentation.

faq.question: How does uv compare to pip or poetry for speed?
faq.answer: uv is 10-100x faster than pip due to its Rust implementation, while remaining less opinionated than Poetry.
